options.text: Albuminocytological dissociation in CSF is characteristic

questions.correct_answer: B. Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases
questions.explanation:
Variant

Description

Autoantibodies

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

Most common in Europe and North America, marked by segmental demyelination.

IgG Anti-GM1, IgG Anti-GQ1b

Axonal Variants (AMAN/AMSAN)

More prevalent in China and Japan, often linked with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

IgG Anti-GM1

Miller Fisher Syndrome

Characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, the best-recognized variant.

Anti-GQ1b

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs, causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia
  • Difficulty handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis or bulbar palsy leading to respiratory failure within hours, Ventilatory support required in 30% of cases

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Loss of proprioception
  • Pain in neck/shoulders similar to over-exercised muscles

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure
  • Arrhythmias
  • Neurogenic shock

Category

Findings

Lumbar Puncture

Elevated CSF protein (100-1000 mg/dL) with normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Timing

Normal findings (<48 hours), protein rise seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

Prolonged F-wave latencies, indicating demyelination (early in AIDP)

Mnemonic: FAME

Flaccid Bilateral Weakness

Areflexia (Option A)

CytoAlbuminologic dissociation (Elevated CSF protein, normal WBC) (Option D)

Monophasic Illness (Symptoms develop over 12 hours to 28 days)

Electrodiagnostic findings consistent with demyelination

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and difficulty with horizontal eye movements. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following syndromes is most consistent with these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Millard-Gu

Condition

Millard-Gubler syndrome

Key Clinical Features

Contralateral hemiplegia (due to corticospinal tract involvement), ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy (resulting in facial paralysis and gaze palsy)

Anatomical Location

Lesion in the ventral pons

Differential Diagnosis

Distinguished from other brainstem syndromes like Foville (involves more extensive gaze palsy), Benedict’s (midbrain involvement), and Wallenberg (lateral medullary syndrome)

Rationale

The clinical features of contralateral hemiplegia with ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy are classic for Millard-Gubler syndrome due to a ventral pontine lesion.

questions.text: Patient is having a headache and confusion. A brain tumor diagnosis is made. Family history reveals brain and kidney tumors. Choose the correct option:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - VHL

Condition

VHL syndrome

Key Features

Brain tumors (hemangioblastomas), kidney tumors (renal cell carcinoma), pheochromocytomas

Diagnosis

Confirmed by genetic testing for VHL gene mutations and imaging studies for tumors

Distinguishing Factors

Presence of both brain and kidney tumors aligns with VHL syndrome

questions.text: What is the confirmatory test for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - NMR S

Condition Differentiation between Tuberculoma and Neurocysticercosis in cases of ring-enhancing brain lesions.
Key Diagnostic Modality NMR Spectroscopy
Associated Imaging Findings Ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, which may be indicative of either tuberculoma or neurocysticercosis.
Rationale for Diagnosis NMR Spectroscopy provides detailed biochemical and chemical information about lesions, helping differentiate between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis.
Differential Diagnosis Use of NMR Spectroscopy to differentiate between tuberculoma (caused by TB) and neurocysticercosis (caused by Taenia solium).
Importance of Confirmation Accurate differentiation between these conditions is crucial for appropriate treatment decisions (antitubercular therapy vs. antiparasitic therapy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exposure to bright light. She occasionally skips breakfast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Migraine

Premonitory (Prodromal) Phase
  • Neck discomfort
  • Cognitive impairment (brain “fog”)
  • Mood changes
  • Fatigue
  • Yawning/sleepiness
  • Increased urination and thirst
  • Food cravings

Aura
  • Neurologic disturbances (e.g., visual disturbances like scintillating scotoma)
  • Due to Cerebral vasoconstriction. Therefore prevention is by Vasodilators.

Headache Phase
  • Pain
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Sensory sensitivities:
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
    • Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound)
    • Osmophobia (sensitivity to smells)
    • Allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli)
    • Vertigo
  • Due to cerebral vasodilation. So treatment is Vasoconstrictors

Postdrome
  • Tiredness
  • Weariness
  • Impaired concentration

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society:

Criteria:

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

 

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

 

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She has difficulty chewing and swallowing, especially in the evening. A Tensilon test is positive. Which investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Evaluation: Recognizing the Signs

  • History:
    • Focus on the onset, progression, diurnal variation and fluctuating muscle weakness.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Assess muscle strength.
    • Identify characteristic signs:
      • Ptosis
      • Diplopia
      • Cogan's lid twitch sign
    • Rule out other neurological conditions.

Diagnostic Tests: Confirming the Suspicion

Test

Description

Tensilon Test
  • Administers edrophonium bromide intravenously.
  • May show transient muscle function improvement; not highly reliable.

Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS)
  • Specialized nerve conduction study.
  • Reveals a decremental response in muscle strength with repeated stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG)
  • SFEMG techniques allow assessment of two important features of the motor unit: jitter and fiber density (FD).
  • SFEMG is the most sensitive clinical test for neuromuscular junction disease and is often abnormal in clinically unaffected muscles in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenia (LEM).

Antibody Testing
  • Detects auto-antibodies related to MG.
  • Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibodies: Most common, block AChR function.
  • Muscle-Specific Kinase (MuSK) Antibodies: Disrupt AChR clustering and stabilization.

Thoracic CT Scan

Essential to rule out thymoma, especially in patients with negative AChR antibody tests.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever for the past week. On examination neck stiffness and Kernig's sign were positive. CSF analysis showed lymphocytosis protein - 8 g/L, glucose - 20 mg/dl while RBS = 140 mg/dl. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms and Clinical Features:
  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.
  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.
  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.
  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.
  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:
  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).
  • High protein content (1-8 g/L).
  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:
  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4-8 weeks, positive in ~50%).
  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10-40%).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:
  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions- tuberculoma

Treatment:
  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.
  • Initial drug regimen: Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Pyridoxine.
  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.
  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).
  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

questions.text: A stroke patient presents with an inability to identify objects but can determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects. Which of the following lobes is involved?
questions.explanation:
Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones.

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Visual agnosia: Inability to recognize visually presented objects despite otherwise normal visual field, acuity, colour vision, brightness, discrimination, language, and memory.
  • Emotional and behavioural changes: Varying behaviours due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Basal gang

Area of Lesion

Consequences

Frontal Lobe
  • Disinhibition and deficits in concentration, orientation, judgment
  • May have reemergence of primitive reflexes.

Frontal Eye Fields
  • Eyes look toward the lesion.

Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation
  • Eyes look away from the side of the lesion.

Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (impaired adduction of ipsilateral eye; nystagmus of contralateral eye with abduction).
  • Eg: Multiple sclerosis

Dominant Parietal Cortex
  • Gerstmann syndrome: Agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, left-right disorientation

Nondominant Parietal Cortex
  • Hemispatial neglect syndrome: Agnosia of the contralateral side of the world.

Hippocampus (Bilateral)
  • Anterograde amnesia: Inability to make new memories.

Basal Ganglia
  • May result in tremors at rest, chorea, and athetosis.
  • Eg: Parkinson disease, Huntington disease.

Subthalamic Nucleus
  • Contralateral hemiballismus.

Mammillary Bodies (Bilateral)
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, memory loss (anterograde and retrograde amnesia), confabulation, personality changes.

Amygdala (Bilateral)
  • Klüver-Bucy syndrome: Disinhibited behavior (eg, hyperphagia, hypersexuality, hyperorality).
  • Eg: HSV-1 encephalitis

Superior Colliculus
  • Parinaud syndrome: Paralysis of conjugate vertical gaze (rostral interstitial nucleus also involved).
  • Eg: Stroke, hydrocephalus, pinealoma.

Reticular Activating System (Midbrain)
  • Reduced levels of arousal and wakefulness (eg, coma).

Cerebellar Hemisphere
  • Intention tremor, limb ataxia, loss of balance; damage to cerebellum → Ipsilateral deficits; fall toward side of lesion.
  • (Cerebellar hemispheres are laterally located and affect lateral limbs)

Cerebellar Vermis
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Dysarthria
  • (Vermis is centrally located and affects central body)

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Dementia

Description

Clinical Findings

Alzheimer's Disease (AD) (Option D)

Most common type of dementia, characterized by amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain.
  • Memory loss, especially short-term memory
  • Disorientation
  • Language difficulties
  • Impaired judgment and reasoning
  • Personality changes
  • Progressive cognitive decline2

Vascular Dementia

Results from damage to blood vessels in the brain, leading to reduced blood flow. Often follows a stroke or series of small strokes.
  • Stepwise progression of cognitive decline
  • Memory loss
  • Impaired executive function
  • Gait disturbances
  • Personality and mood changes
  • Signs of previous strokes (e.g., hemiparesis)

Lewy Body Dementia

Caused by abnormal protein deposits (Lewy bodies) in the brain, affecting cognitive and motor functions.
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity)
  • Cognitive fluctuations
  • Memory impairment
  • REM sleep behavior disorder

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)

Characterized by degeneration in the frontal and temporal lobes, often with personality and behavioral changes.
  • Personality and behavior changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy)
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Lack of empathy
  • Impulsive behaviors
  • Social withdrawal

Mixed Dementia

A combination of Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. Common in elderly patients.
  • Symptoms of both Alzheimer's and vascular dementia
  • Cognitive decline with stepwise progression
  • Memory problems
  • Behavioral changes
  • Motor problems (e.g., gait disturbances)

Parkinson's Disease Dementia

Occurs in patients with Parkinson's disease, typically years after motor symptoms begin.
  • Memory loss
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Attention deficits
  • Executive dysfunction
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor)

Huntington's Disease

(Option C)

Genetic disorder characterized by progressive motor, cognitive, and psychiatric decline.
  • Involuntary movements (chorea)
  • Memory impairment
  • Personality changes (e.g., irritability, depression)
  • Impaired coordination and motor function
  • Progressive dementia

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)

(Option B)

Rare prion disease causing rapid neurodegeneration, often with fatal progression.
  • Rapid onset of dementia
  • Motor symptoms (e.g., ataxia, myoclonus)
  • Visual disturbances
  • Psychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression)
  • Death usually within 1-2 years

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome

Caused by thiamine deficiency, often due to alcohol abuse. Can lead to brain damage and dementia.
  • Amnesia (anterograde and retrograde)
  • Confabulation
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Neurological abnormalities due to thiamine deficiency

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

A condition where excess cerebrospinal fluid accumulates in the brain ventricles, leading to cognitive decline.
  • Gait disturbances (shuffling walk)
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Enlargement of the ventricles on brain imaging

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done, and it showed predominantly lymphocytes, sugar- 50mg, and protein- 3000mg/dl. Cobweb coagulum was noted. Gram-staining was negative. The patient's chest X-ray shows upper lobe involvement with hilar lymph node enlargement.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Tuberculous meningitis

Tuberculous Meningitis

Symptoms and Clinical Features:

  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.

  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.

  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.

  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.

  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.

  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.

  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:

  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).

  • High protein content (1–8 g/L).

  • Cobweb Coagulum: Clear fluid in a test tube with a cobweb at the bottom

  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:

  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4–8 weeks, positive in ~50%).

  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10–40%).

  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:

 

  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions -tuberculoma

Treatment:

  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.

  • Initial drug regimen: isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine.

  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.

  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).

  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Subarachnoid haemorrhage

Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Etiology, Risk factors and Pathophysiology

  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.

  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.

  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).

  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology

  • Age: Most aSAH occurs between ages 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.

  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology

  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):

    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.

    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)

      • Age >60

      • Posterior circulation aneurysms

      • Atherosclerosis

      • Aneurysm size

        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.

        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.

        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.

      • Family history

      • Previous SAH

      • ADPKD

  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):

    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.

    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.

    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.

    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.

    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology

  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.

  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.

    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.

    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

Clinical Presentation

 

  • "Thunderclap headache" - worst headache of life

  • Sudden onset severe headache

  • Vomiting

  • Variable LOC

  • Meningismus

  • Retinal hemorrhages

  • Focal neurologic deficits

  • Nuchal rigidity

Diagnosis

CT Head

  • Non-contrast CT is first-line

  • "Star sign" - blood in basal cisterns

  • Sensitivity: 98-100% in first 12 hours

Lumbar Puncture

  • If CT negative

  • Xanthochromia (takes 12h to develop)

  • Elevated opening pressure

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Guillain-Barré syndrome

Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improves as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the probable cause of her headaches?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Pseudotumor cerebri

Pseudotumor Cerebri / Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

A disorder associated with elevated CSF pressure without obvious cause, commonly affecting young, obese females

Key Symptoms
  • Headache (worse on waking and with recumbency)
  • Visual disturbances (may be transient)
  • Can occur without visual problems
  • Worse in morning or after lying down
  • Pulsatile tinnitus may be present

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Elevated CSF pressure (>20-25 cm H2O)
  • Normal MRI/MRV findings
  • Normal neurological examination (except for papilledema)
  • Papilledema may be present (but not required for diagnosis)

Initial Treatment
  • Acetazolamide (250-500 mg)
  • Weight loss (if overweight)
  • Serial lumbar punctures may be needed
  • Regular ophthalmologic monitoring

Secondary Treatment
  • Topiramate
  • Other carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • CSF shunting procedures (if needed)
  • Weight loss management programs

Monitoring
  • Regular visual field testing
  • Ophthalmic examination
  • CSF pressure monitoring
  • Weight monitoring
  • Headache diary

Important Considerations
  • Fundoscopic exam should be performed even without overt ophthalmic involvement
  • Consider diagnosis in chronic migraine cases
  • May require long-term management
  • Early intervention is crucial for preventing vision loss

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Myasthenia gravis

Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Clinical Features
  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia
  • Weakness in oculomotor, pharyngeal, limb, neck extensors
  • Fluctuation and fatigue worse with activity, improved by rest
  • Fatiguability increases as the day passes (diurnal variation)
  • Initial symptoms frequently ocular (diplopia/ptosis)
  • Facial weakness produces "snarling" expression

Physical Examination
  • Eye movements and ptosis
  • Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities
  • Weakness following repetitive muscle activation
  • Normal deep tendon reflexes
  • No sensory abnormalities
  • Symptoms relieved by Anticholinesterases

Diagnostic Tests
  • Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% generalized MG)
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies (in ~40% of AChR-negative cases)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Single-fiber EMG
  • CT or MRI of chest (to evaluate thymus)

Clinical Tests
  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: 2mg + 8mg IV
  • Ice pack test for ptosis
  • Fatigue testing (repeated muscle activation)

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves:

options.label: A
options.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

options.label: B
options.text: Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral lower half of the face

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral lower half of the face

questions.correct_answer: A. Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

Bell’s Palsy

Causes
  • Inflammation of facial nerve
  • HSV-1 reactivation- Common cause
  • VZV reactivation in Ramsay Hunt
  • Edema within facial canal

Clinical Features
  • Acute onset (24-72 hours)
  • Complete unilateral facial paralysis
  • Loss of taste anterior 2/3 tongue
  • Hyperacusis (stapedius paralysis)
  • Decreased tear production
  • Bell's phenomenon present

Diagnostic Approach
  • Clinical diagnosis primary
  • EMG/NCS if no improvement
  • MRI if atypical features
  • CSF analysis if indicated
  • Lyme titers in endemic areas

Treatment & Prognosis
  • Prednisone 60-80mg × 5 days
  • Valacyclovir 1000mg TID × 5-7 days
  • Eye protection crucial
  • 80% recovery rate
  • Axonal degeneration = worse prognosis
  • Incomplete paralysis in 1st week = best prognosis

questions.text: Where is the site of the lesion that leads to the occurrence of hemiballismus in a patient displaying forceful, flinging movements?
questions.explanation:
Movement disorder

Lesions

Chorea

Lesions in the putamen

Dystonia

Lesions in the globus pallidus

Ballism/Hemiballismus

Lesion in subthalamic nucleus (STN)

Huntington’s Disease (HD)

Lesions in the caudate nucleus

Sydenham's chorea

Rheumatic heart disease

Condition

Description

Tremor

Rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions.

Dystonia

Involuntary, patterned, sustained, or repeated muscle contractions often associated with twisting movements and abnormal posture.

Athetosis

Slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect the arms and hands (this represents a form of dystonia with increased mobility).

Chorea

Rapid, semipurposeful, graceful, dance like non patterned involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups. When the movements are of large amplitude and predominant proximal distribution, the term ballism is used.

Ballismus

Violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body

Myoclonus

Sudden, brief (<100 ms), jerklike, arrhythmic muscle twitches.

Tic

Brief, repeated, stereotyped muscle contractions that can often be suppressed for a short time. These can be simple and involve a single muscle group or complex and affect a range of motor activities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.correct_answer: A. CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion:

Workup for stroke

Initial Assessment and Stabilization
  • Upon arrival, ensure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are stable.
  • Blood glucose levels should be checked quickly to address hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Determining Stroke Type: Imaging is Key
  • A non-contrast CT scan is the primary imaging modality for differentiating between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.
  • Clinical features may suggest stroke type, but imaging is essential for confirmation as no clinical finding can definitively differentiate between the two.

Further Investigations: Uncovering the Cause
  • Detailed History and Physical Exam: Consider risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, etc.) and perform a neurological exam to localize the affected brain area.
  • Laboratory Tests: Perform CBC, electrolytes, renal function, blood glucose, lipid profile, coagulation studies, ESR, and ECG (to detect arrhythmias and signs of recent MI).

Visualizing the Cerebral Vasculature: Imaging Techniques
  • CT Angiography (CTA): Assesses cerebral vasculature and identifies blockages/stenosis, but is performed after non-contrast CT has ruled out hemorrhage (not for stroke type differentiation).
  • CT Perfusion Imaging: Assesses blood flow, identifying reduced perfusion and ischemic penumbra.
  • MRI: Provides more detail but takes longer than CT and is not as widely available, thus not the first imaging choice for acute stroke evaluation. (Option B)
  • MRA: Offers detailed images of blood vessels, similar to CTA.
  • Cerebral Angiography: Gold standard for vessel evaluation, used when other techniques are inconclusive or before endovascular intervention.
  • Ultrasound Techniques: Carotid Duplex Ultrasonography assesses carotid stenosis but is not a first-line acute imaging modality; Transcranial Doppler (TCD) measures blood flow velocity in intracranial arteries.

Tailoring Investigations Based on Stroke Type
  • Ischemic Stroke: Focuses on identifying the source of the blockage (cardioembolic, artery-to-artery embolic, small vessel disease).
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Investigations focus on identifying causes of bleeding (e.g., hypertension, aneurysm, vascular malformation).

Subacute combined degeneration

Description
  • Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts

Etiology
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians) Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection

Clinical features
  • Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement
  • Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement
  • Ataxia: Romberg sign positive
  • DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement)
  • Dementia: reversible with therapy
  • Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints

Investigations
  • Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation
  • Peripheral blood smear: may reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils

 

  • NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well

Management
  • Vitamin B12 supplements

Differential diagnosis
  • Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioural change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Clinical Triad
  • Gait disturbance: Progressive difficulties in walking
  • Urinary issues: Urgency or incontinence
  • Cognitive impairment: Decline in cognitive functions

Imaging Characteristics
  • Ventriculomegaly is typically seen
  • Evans ratio: the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy.
  • An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy.
  • A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci.
  • CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause for a 22-year-old man who has a high-grade fever, a purpuric rash, and a CSF sample showing gram-negative diplococci?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features

Description

Consciousness

Decreased level of consciousness occurs in >75% of cases, ranging from lethargy to coma.

Kernig's Sign

Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

Brudzinski's Sign

Positive when passive flexion of the neck results in spontaneous flexion of the hips and knees; also indicative of meningeal irritation.

Pupils

May present as dilated and poorly reactive due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

Posturing

Possible decerebrate posturing as a sign of severe CNS dysfunction.

Signs of Increased ICP

Includes elevated CSF opening pressure (>180 mmH2O), papilledema, and potential cerebral herniation (1–8% incidence).

Additional Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, photophobia; seizures in 15–40% (focal or generalized).

Meningococcemia Rash

Erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly becomes petechial, commonly on the trunk and lower extremities.

questions.text: A 72-year-old former pilot visits a neurologist, accompanied by his wife, exhibiting symptoms of rapidly advancing dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual impairments. The provided FLAIR MRI scans can assist in confirming the diagnosis. What is the probable diagnosis?

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) findings

 

 

 

 

 

Electroencephalography (EEG)
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC)
  • These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

MRI findings
  • DWI or FLAIR MRI has a sensitivity of 98% and specificity of 93%
  • DWI: Increased intensity in the basal ganglia, thalamus, and cortex
  • Cortical ribboning
  • Hockey stick or pulvinar sign is seen in variant, infectious, or acquired CJD

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important pathophysiological mechanism for Berry aneurysm?

options.label: A
options.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.correct_answer: B. Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect
questions.explanation:
Berry Aneurysm

Definition
  • Saccular outpouching of intracranial arterial wall
  • Represents 90% of cerebral aneurysms
  • Primary location: Circle of Willis
  • Most common sites:
    • Anterior communicating/anterior cerebral junction
    • Posterior communicating/internal carotid junction
    • Middle cerebral artery bifurcation
    • Basilar apex

Pathophysiological Mechanisms

Structural Changes:

  • Most important- Internal elastic lamina disruption
  • Media layer thinning
  • Adventitial layer remodeling

Molecular Mechanisms:

  • Inflammatory mediator activation
  • Matrix metalloproteinase upregulation
  • Vessel wall extracellular matrix degradation

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Wall shear stress elevation
  • Flow-related endothelial injury
  • Intramural stress distribution alterations

Histopathological Classification

1. Mycotic:

  • Infectious arterial wall damage
  • Distal vessel predilection
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration

2. Arteriosclerotic:

  • Intimal hyperplasia
  • Media degeneration
  • Elastic fiber fragmentation

3. Traumatic:

  • Transmural disruption
  • False lumen formation
  • Adventitial hemorrhage

Rupture Risk Stratification

Morphological Criteria:

  • Size >7mm: high risk
  • Aspect ratio >1.6
  • Daughter sac presence
  • Wall irregularity

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Systolic BP >140 mmHg
  • Flow pattern alterations
  • Intrasaccular pressure gradients

Genetic Markers:

  • Collagen deficiency
  • Elastic fiber abnormalities
  • Matrix metalloproteinase polymorphisms

Clinical Manifestations

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Hunt-Hess grading scale correlation
  • Fisher scale for CT findings
  • Modified Rankin Scale outcomes

Mass Effect:

  • Cranial nerve compression syndromes
  • Brainstem compression sequelae
  • Hydrocephalus development

Thromboembolic Events:

  • Watershed infarction patterns
  • Perforator occlusion syndromes
  • Distal embolization phenomena
